Thanks to everybody (Cedric, Elliotte, James, Adam, Paul and J.B.) for
help=
ing me out.  I've learned alot from this thread.  And - I've
ordered JUnit =
Recipes from Amazon.

Having just started with JUnit and with the idea of w=
riting tests for
all of my code, I must say that I'm delighted with the res=
ults.  Oh -
I'm not writing much new code.  Most of the unit tests are for =
code
that already exists for which I'm fixing bugs.

There isn't much suppo=
rt for tests on my team because we tend to be in
fire-fighting mode all the=
 time. So, of course, we'll right good tests
"later".  However, the tests h=
ave helped me much more than I would
have expected with:

* developing a fa=
ster, deeper understanding of the code I'm working with

* improving the de=
sign of existing code (so that I can actually test something!)

* giving me=
 the confidence to make changes and knowing that I'm not
breaking related c=
ode

* thinking more deeply about what I'm doing

I really can't imagine go=
ing back to not writing tests.  Now the thing
I need to do next is figure o=
ut how to build support for running a
suite of tests as part of our build p=
rocess and getting our other
developers to create and run tests, too.

Than=
k you all again -

Chris
